The Buddha said:

If one cultivates the body, precepts, mind, and wisdom as explained above, and is able to observe all dharmas as being the same as empty space, not seeing wisdom, not seeing the wise, not seeing foolishness, not seeing the foolish, not seeing cultivation and the cultivator, this is called a wise one.
Such a person is able to cultivate the body, precepts, mind, and wisdom. This person is able to cause the retribution of hell to be experienced lightly in the present life.
If such a person were to create extremely grave evil karma, through contemplation and observation, they would be able to make it light. They would think like this:
'Although my karma is grave, it is not as good as good karma.'
It is like a hundred pounds of artificial flowers, which can never match a single ounce of real gold.
If one were to throw a pint of salt into the Ganges River, the water would not have a salty taste, and the drinker would not notice it.
It is like a wealthy person who, although owing many millions of treasures to others, is unable to be bound by them and made to suffer.
Like a great fragrant elephant, able to break iron chains and go freely.
A wise person is also like this, always thinking:
'My good power is great, and evil karma is weak.
I can confess and repent to remove evil, and cultivate wisdom.
The power of wisdom is great, and the power of ignorance is small.'
Having thought like this, he gets close to good friends, cultivates right views, upholds, recites, copies, and explains the twelve divisions of the scriptures.

Seeing those who uphold, recite, copy, and explain them, he gives rise to respect and also offers them clothing, food, dwellings, bedding, medicine, flowers, and incense, praising and respecting them.
Wherever he goes, he praises their goodness and does not speak of their faults.
